Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the CWPO of MO over Fe-MOF catalysts with ready-made H2O2 (CWPO-I) and over Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts with in-situ generated H2O2 (CWPO-II). Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Adsorption capacity of Fe-MOFs in the absence of H2O2 and (b) their reaction performances for the CWPO-I of MO with H2O2. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Weight losses of Fe-MOFs after the CWPO-I reaction. Fig 3 Fig. 4 PXRD patterns of fresh and recycled Fe-MOFs before and after the CWPO-I reaction. Fig 4 Fig. 5 TEM images of Pd/Fe-MOFs and their Pd NP size distributions. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Pd 3d XPS spectra of Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Pd2+/Pd0 ratios and Pd contents (wt. %) of Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts, calculated from their deconvoluted Pd 3d XPS spectra and determined by ICP-OES, respectively. Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a) Adsorption capacity of Pd/Fe-MOFs in the absence of H2O2 and (b) their reaction performances for the CWPO-II of MO with in-situ generated H2O2. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Postulated reaction mechanism of CWPO-II over the Pd/MIL-100(Fe) catalyst for MO degradation. This study aimed to develop an elegant strategy to overcome the limitations of conventional dosage-dependent Fenton-like reactions, which require excessive use of metal salts and oxidants, inevitably leading to sludge formation and necessitating complex, energy-intensive post-treatment before disposal into the environment. To achieve this goal, catalytic wet peroxide oxidation (CWPO) was explored using both pre-added H2O2 (CWPO-I) and in-situ generated H2O2 (CWPO-II). For this purpose, four different Fe-based metal-organic frameworks (Fe-MOFs), e.g., MIL-88A, MIL-101(Fe), Fe-MOF-74, and MIL-100(Fe), along with their Pd-supported counterparts (Pd/Fe-MOFs) were prepared and evaluated for their catalytic activity in the CWPO of methyl orange (MO). Although Fe-MOFs effectively promoted the CWPO-I of MO, their coordinated structures were highly susceptible to reactive oxygen species (ROS) attacks, resulting in significant mass loss and decreased catalytic activity after the reaction. In contrast, Pd/Fe-MOFs demonstrated excellent stability in CWPO-II, suggesting that the relatively low H2O2 concentration generated in-situ helped preserve the Fe-MOF structures and maintain their catalytic activity. Furthermore, the MO degradation rates of Pd/MIL-101(Fe) and Pd/MIL-100(Fe) in CWPO-II (1361 and 1992 × 10–5 mmol/h, respectively) exceeded those of their counterparts in CWPO-I (1097 and 1657 × 10–5 mmol/h, respectively). This superior efficiency can be attributed to the sufficient in-situ generation of H2O2 on Pd sites and the subsequent efficient ROS generation on Fe nodes. Pd/MIL-100(Fe) exhibited the highest MO degradation rate and excellent recyclability, maintaining its catalytic activity over four cycles. These findings clearly demonstrate that the CWPO-II approach, leveraging in-situ generated H2O2, offers an efficient wastewater treatment strategy without the need for additional chemicals that could negatively impact the ecosystem. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic wet peroxide oxidation Metal-organic frameworks Organic dye degradation Direct synthesis of H2O2 Bifunctional catalyst Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) are widely recognized as environmentally friendly, sustainable, and effective methods for wastewater treatment [1,2]. These methods, including H2O2-based processes (such as Fenton and photo-Fenton reactions) [3–7] as well as alternative approaches (e.g., sonolysis and UV/O3) [8–11], have been extensively studied in the pursuit of more efficient water purification strategies. In H2O2-based AOPs, reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as hydroxyl radicals (•OH), superoxide radicals (•O2⁻), and sulfate radicals, are generated through the in-situ decomposition of H2O2 and can efficiently degrade various organic pollutants into non-toxic by-products, such as CO2 and H2O. Among these ROS, the hydroxyl radical (•OH), recognized as the second strongest oxidant with an oxidation potential of 2.8 eV, has proven particularly effective in degrading hazardous and recalcitrant organic pollutants [12]. This is especially crucial for wastewater treatment in the textile industry, where organic dyes with high aromatic content and low biodegradability pose significant environmental challenges. Although H2O2-based AOPs and Fenton-like methods exhibit superior efficacy in degrading organic pollutants, their dosage-dependent nature necessitates substantial amounts of homogeneous catalysts and oxidants to generate sufficient ROS, posing an additional environmental burden. Furthermore, the acidic reaction conditions typically required to prevent the formation of undesirable iron sludge [13–15] demand complex and energy-intensive post-treatments to remove salts generated during neutralization, as well as excess dissolved catalysts and oxidants. Recently, catalytic wet peroxide oxidation (CWPO) has emerged as a promising alternative to overcome the inherent limitations of conventional H2O2-based AOPs. This process relies on the catalytic decomposition of H2O2 over a heterogeneous catalyst to generate hydroxyl radicals. The use of a water-insoluble catalyst in CWPO can help minimize by-product formation and sludge generation [16,17]. In particular, Y. Ying and co-workers reported that Fe-incorporated porous PAN fiber (Fe-PAN) [18,19], Fe-, Cu-incorporated CNT (Fe-Cu-CNT) [20], and Fe-incorporated CNT-microfibrous composite (Fe-CNT-MF) [21] showed excellent activity in degradation of various organic matters. They also reported that BiOI/Bi4O5Br2 microcluster efficiently promoted the visible-light-induced photocatalytic degradation of methylparaben [22]. To further mitigate by-product formation, a CWPO process utilizing in-situ generated H2O2 instead of excessive pre-supplied H2O2 can be considered an ideal approach. In this context, we have demonstrated that the CWPO of an organic dye can be efficiently carried out over heterogeneous bifunctional catalysts by supplying hydrogen and air, without the need for external H2O2 addition [23,24]. While in-situ H2O2 generation strategies have been employed in photo-Fenton and electro-Fenton systems [25–27], it is important to note that these earlier studies required the separation of dissolved iron species and the associated sludge after the reaction, posing additional challenges. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous crystalline materials consisting of metal ion nodes or clusters, known as secondary building units (SBUs), linked by organic ligands [28–30]. Their large surface area, tunable porosity, structural flexibility, abundant active sites, and diverse functionalities have made MOFs highly attractive as heterogeneous catalysts for the degradation of organic pollutants in wastewater [31,32]. In this context, various MOFs have been explored as potential catalysts for the degradation of organic pollutants via the CWPO reaction as summarized in Table S1. Among various MOFs, iron-based MOFs (Fe-MOFs) stand out for their high catalytic activity in removing organic dyes from wastewater, outperforming other transition metal-based MOFs (e.g., Cu, Co). Their superior activity is attributed to unique interfacial electron transfer properties and the Fe(III)/Fe(II) redox couple. Moreover, Fe-MOFs are considered promising candidates for environmentally benign catalysis due to the low toxicity and natural abundance of iron [23,33–35]. However, despite their advantages, Fe-MOFs face inherent challenges, including limited catalytic activity, structural instability under harsh conditions, and susceptibility to degradation by specific reactants and products [36]. To address these challenges, the manipulation and control of morphology, Lewis acid sites (LAS), and other structural properties of Fe-MOFs have emerged as significant research topics [37]. For instance, Liao et al. investigated the impact of morphological variations in MIL-88A on its performance in CWPO for phenol removal. Their findings revealed that rod-shaped MIL-88A exhibited superior catalytic efficiency compared to other morphologies, such as spindle-like or diamond-like structures [38]. Likewise, MIL-53(Fe) demonstrated enhanced performance in rhodamine B degradation, surpassing ozonation due to its abundant LAS and improved mass transfer properties resulting from its optimal porosity [39]. Despite the promising potential of Fe-MOFs in CWPO for dye degradation, the influence of their physicochemical properties on catalytic performance in CWPO reactions remains largely unexplored. In this study, a series of Fe-MOFs were synthesized using various organic ligands, and their catalytic activities for the CWPO of methyl orange (MO) with ready-made H2O2 were evaluated (CWPO-I). Multidentate carboxylate organic linkers (-COO-) were selected due to their ability to facilitate the design of MOFs with diverse topologies [40]. In this context, four distinct Fe-MOFs, including Fe-MOF-74, MIL-88A, MIL-100(Fe), and MIL-101(Fe), each featuring different carboxylate linkers, were prepared. Furthermore, to develop an environmentally sustainable wastewater treatment process with minimal environmental impact, Pd/Fe-MOFs were synthesized and employed as bifunctional catalysts in the CWPO reaction using hydrogen and air instead of excessive ready-made H2O2 (CWPO-II). As discussed in later sections, the physicochemical properties of Fe-MOFs play a pivotal role in facilitating in-situ H2O2 generation on Pd and enhancing MO degradation through ROS generated on Fe. These findings clearly demonstrate that the CWPO-II process, utilizing bifunctional Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts with in-situ generated H2O2, presents a promising strategy for efficient wastewater treatment with minimal by-product formation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O, 98 %), fumaric acid (99 %), nitric acid (HNO3, 60 %), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 34.5 wt %), dimethylformamide (DMF, 99 %), ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.5 %), and methanol (CH3OH, 99.8 %) were purchased from Samchun Chemicals (Seoul, South Korea). Methyl orange (C14H14N3NaO3S, dye content 85 %), 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (DHTA, 98 %) palladium (II) acetate (Pd(OAc)2, 99.9 %), trimesic acid (H3BTC, 95 %), terephthalic acid, iron powder, hydrofluoric acid (HF, 40 %) and ferroin indicator (0.1 wt % in H2O) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Cerium (IV) sulfate (Ce(SO4)2, 0.1 N standard solution) was purchased from Merck Millipore. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation A series of Fe-MOFs were synthesized via hydrothermal/solvothermal methods using Fe precursors as metal sources and distinct carboxylate organic linkers. MIL-88A was prepared following previously reported procedures with slight modifications [38,41,42]. In a typical synthesis, FeCl3⋅6H2O (4 mmol) and fumaric acid (4 mmol) were each dissolved separately in 10 mL of deionized water. The FeCl3⋅6H2O solution was then added to the fumaric acid solution, and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 373 K for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the orange precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed three times with deionized water. Finally, the sample was dried in a vacuum oven at 353 K for 6 h. Fe-MOF-74 was synthesized by dissolving FeCl3⋅6H2O (1.97 mmol) and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (0.3 mmol) in a mixed solvent consisting of 20 mL of DMF, 1.5 mL of ethanol, and 1.5 mL of deionized water. The solution was magnetically stirred at room temperature for 30 min. Subsequently, the mixture underwent ultrasonic treatment for 10 min to achieve a well-dispersed suspension. This suspension was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 393 K for 24 h. After natural cooling to room temperature, the resulting Fe-MOF-74 was thoroughly washed with DMF and ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 333 K for 12 h [43]. MIL-100(Fe) was synthesized via a hydrothermal reaction of trimesic acid with iron powder, hydrofluoric acid, nitric acid, and H2O at 423 K for 12 h in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, with slight modifications from previously reported methods [44,45]. The reaction mixture had a molar composition of 1.0 Fe: 0.67 BTC: 2.0 HF: 0.6 HNO3: 277 H2O. The reaction products were purified by refluxing in boiling water at 353 K for 5 h, followed by hot ethanol treatment at 333 K for 3 h. Finally, the resulting orange solids were dried at 353 K for 12 h under vacuum. MIL-101(Fe) was synthesized following literature reports [46,47], with some modifications. Briefly, FeCl3⋅6H2O (5 mmol) and terephthalic acid (2.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of DMF and sonicated for 20 min. The resulting mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 383 K for 24 h. The product was then washed three times with DMF and hot ethanol (333 K, 3 h). Finally, the orange solid was dried in an oven at 343 K for 12 h. Pd impregnation on Fe-MOF was carried out using the alcohol-reduction method [48]. A slurry solution containing Pd(OAc)2 (21.1 mg), ethanol (20 mL), and Fe-MOF (0.5 g) was stirred at ambient temperature for 24 h (Pd intake 2 wt %). The resulting Pd/Fe-MOF catalyst was then filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried at 393 K for 12 h. 2.3 Characterization The crystalline structure of both Fe-MOFs and Pd/Fe-MOFs was examined using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns, obtained with a Malvern Panalytical Empyrean instrument equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å). The specific surface area and pore volume of the MOF catalysts were measured using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K on a BELSORP-Max instrument (BEL, Japan). Prior to the experiments, all samples were degassed at 423 K under vacuum overnight. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model was used to determine the specific surface area of the samples. The particle size distribution and the electronic properties of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) on Fe-MOFs were analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), respectively. The surface morphology was observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM; SU8820, Hitachi, Japan) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). TEM analyses and X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping were conducted using a Titan G2 ChemiSTEM™ (FEI Company, USA) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. XPS measurements were performed on an Axis Supra+ (Kratos Analytical, UK) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation at a pass energy of 40 eV. The binding energies of the chemical species were calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was conducted using an FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with a diffuse reflectance chamber (Pike Technologies, USA). The Pd content on Fe-MOFs was determined using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, OPTIMA 7300 DV, PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA, USA). UV–visible spectra were recorded using a PerkinElmer Lambda 25 spectrophotometer (Waltham, MA, USA) over a wavelength range of 300–800 nm at room temperature. 2.4 Catalytic wet peroxide oxidation The CWPO-I and CWPO-II reactions were carried out using Fe-MOF catalysts with ready-made H2O2 and Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts with in-situ generated H2O2, respectively [23]. Both CWPO reactions were performed at 293 K under atmospheric pressure in a three-necked round-bottom flask equipped with a thermocouple. For the CWPO-I reaction, 0.05 g of Fe-MOF was first dispersed in 150 mL of an aqueous solution of MO dye (50 mg/L). Then, 0.42 mL of H2O2 (1.8 M) was added to adjust the final concentration of H2O2 to 5 mM. The CWPO-I reaction was initiated by vigorous stirring of the reaction mixture (600 rpm) and maintained for 3 h. The CWPO-II reaction was performed in the presence of a Pd/Fe-MOF catalyst under the same reaction conditions as CWPO-I. However, instead of directly using ready-made H2O2, mixed gases – 5 % H2/N2 (90 mL/min) and 20 % O2/N2 (as model air, 30 mL/min) – were supplied at a total flow rate of 120 mL/min (H2/O2/N2 ratio of 3.8/5.0/91.2) using two mass flow controllers (Brooks 5850E, Netherlands) to generate H2O2, promoted by Pd. During the reaction, liquid samples were periodically extracted and analyzed using a UV/Vis spectrophotometer. The extent of MO decomposition was determined by monitoring changes in the absorption peak intensity at 464 nm, based on a calibration curve established prior to the experiment. The MO conversion ( %) and degradation rate (mmol/h) were calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) MO Conversion ( % ) = Δ C × 100 C 0 (2) M O D e g r a d a t i o n R a t e ( m m o l / h ) = Δ C × V M M O × t where ΔC represents the difference between the initial MO concentration (C₀, ppm) and the concentration at a specific time (Cₜ, ppm). The other variables are defined as follows: V (L) is the total volume of the liquid (150 mL); MMO is the molecular weight of MO; and t (h) represents the reaction time. 2.5 Direct synthesis of H2O2 (DSHP), H2O2 decomposition, and H2O2 hydrogenation The DSHP reaction was performed in the absence of any caustic additives, as described in our previous reports [49–52]. For instance, 20 mg of catalyst and 50 g of a methanol/water solution (80 wt % MeOH) were charged into a 100 mL jacketed high-pressure reactor (Büchiglas Picoclave, Switzerland) connected to a circulator (Julabo F25-HF, Germany). First, to remove any gaseous impurities from the reactor, nitrogen was supplied. Then, mixed H2/N2 (5 mol % H2) and O2/N2 (20 mol % O2) gases were introduced simultaneously with total flow rate of 120 mL/min (H2/O2/N2 ratio of 3.8/5.0/91.2). During the reaction, the reactor pressure was gradually increased to 30 bar using two high-pressure mass flow controllers (Brooks 5850E, Netherlands) and maintained with a back-pressure regulator (BPR, Tescom, USA). After stabilization at 30 bar and 275 K, the reaction proceeded for 1 h under vigorous stirring (1200 rpm). Off-gas was collected in a gas bag and analyzed using a GC (Agilent 6890, USA) equipped with a Carboxen-1010 PLOT capillary column and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to determine the H2 conversion. At the end of the reaction, the reactor pressure was reduced to atmospheric pressure, and the reaction product was separated from the catalyst by filtration for titration. The H2O2 concentration was measured by titrating the reaction product with a cerium sulfate (Ce(SO4)2) solution in the presence of a ferroin indicator. H2O2 productivity was defined as the amount of H2O2 produced per hour per unit mass of Pd (mmol H2O2/g Pd h). Decomposition and hydrogenation of H2O2 were conducted at 275 K under atmospheric pressure. For the H2O2 decomposition test, 20 mg of catalyst was introduced into a methanol/water solution containing 1 wt % H2O2. The reaction was carried out for 1 h at 275 K under a nitrogen atmosphere. For the hydrogenation of H2O2, hydrogen was bubbled through the solution at a rate of 10 mL/min instead of nitrogen. The variation in H2O2 concentration over time was determined by titrating liquid samples regularly extracted from the reaction solution. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Strategy for CWPO of MO with ready-made and in-situ generated H2O2 As shown in Fig. 1 , the CWPO of MO was performed over Fe-MOF catalysts with ready-made H2O2 (CWPO-I) or over Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts with in-situ generated H2O2 (CWPO-II). Each Fe-MOF has its characteristic linkers such as aliphatic carboxylate ligands for MIL-88(A), aromatic di-carboxylate ligands for MIL-101(Fe), aromatic tri-carboxylate ligands for MIL-100(Fe), and aromatic di-carboxylate linkers with hydroxyl groups (OH) for Fe-MOF-74, which differentiates the textural properties and stability. In the case of CWPO-I, the Fe-MOF catalysts were used for the generation of ROS from pre-added H2O2 in solution, their efficiency for MO degradation and structural integrity under highly oxidative reaction conditions was investigated. On the other hand, The CWPO-II reaction aimed to overcome the instability of MOF catalysts under oxidative reaction conditions [23] by maintaining the H2O2 concentration in the solution as low as possible. For this purpose, the CWPO-II was carried out using Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts by supplying air and hydrogen without direct addition of H2O2. In this CWPO-II reaction, in-situ generation of H2O2 from oxygen and hydrogen over Pd, rapid generation of ROS over Fe, and decomposition of MO by the ROS proceeded in a consecutive manner. 3.2 CWPO-I over Fe-MOF catalysts Because organic dyes can easily adsorb on porous materials such as MOFs, the adsorption capacity of Fe-MOFs in the absence of H2O2 and their reaction performances for CWPO-I of MO with H2O2 were investigated. As presented in Fig. 2 and Fig. S1, the amount of adsorbed MO increased in the order of Fe-MOF-74 < MIL-88A < MIL-100(Fe) < MIL-101(Fe). While higher adsorption of MO on MIL-100(Fe) and MIL-101(Fe) with relatively large surface areas and pore volumes was expected, the considerable MO adsorption on MIL-88A with the smallest surface area and pore volume (approximately 26±0.5 %) and the very low MO adsorption capacity of Fe-MOF-74 (3 ± 0.03 %) were interesting, which indicates that there are other factors affecting the degree of adsorption. The CWPO-I reaction performances of Fe-MOF catalysts, with the exception of Fe-MOF-74, roughly agreed with their adsorption capacity. Although the difference in the MO conversion (or removal) between CWPO-1 and adsorption does not indicate actual MO degradation by CWPO-1, it seems that the observed catalytic activities of MIL-88A and MIL-101(Fe) for MO removal may arise from both MO adsorption and degradation. The increased MO conversion obtained from the CWPO-1 over the MIL-100(Fe) catalyst suggests that MIL-100(Fe) can also efficiently promote the MO degradation reaction. The most interesting result is the Fe-MOF-74 catalyst showed the highest MO degradation rate and conversion as high as 2095 ± 47 × 10–5 mmol/h and 94±0.2 %, respectively. Considering its very low MO adsorption capacity, the reaction performance of Fe-MOF-74 for MO decomposition overwhelmed those of the other Fe-MOFs. The result implied that the nature of organic linker is a key factor determining both adsorption capacity and catalytic activity of a Fe-MOF for MO removal. It seems that the hydroquinone linkers connected to Fe metal nodes offered a more favorable surface for accelerating ROS formation [53,54]. In order to examine the stability of Fe-MOF catalysts under the CWPO-I reaction conditions, recovered catalysts were analyzed and re-evaluated. Although it was difficult to avoid instability issues during the CWPO-I reaction regardless of the type of Fe-MOF, the degree of structural deformation and weight loss varied. As shown in Table 1 and Fig. S2, both surface areas and pore volumes of Fe-MOFs were decreased after the CWPO-I reaction. Particularly, the textural properties of MIL-101(Fe) deteriorated significantly. This result might be attributed to the relatively low thermodynamic stability of MIL-101(Fe), which leads to its slow conversion into denser forms, resulting in instability under harsh conditions [55]. Fig. 3 shows the weight loss of each Fe-MOF catalyst after the CWPO-I reaction. The significant weight losses of MIL-101(Fe), Fe-MOF-74, and MIL-100(Fe) indicated that the coordinated MOF structures were vulnerable to ROS attacks regardless of ligand types, and metal leaching occurred during the reactions. In this context, the relatively lower weight loss of MIL-88A can be explained by its dense structure with small pores and/or its low activity for ROS generation. These two aspects may be advantageous in retaining its structure against ROS attacks. The changed colors also indicated structural deformation or deterioration of Fe-MOFs. In this regard, PXRD analysis was conducted to investigate the changes in the crystalline structure of each Fe-MOF. As presented in Fig. 4 , the diffraction peaks of fresh Fe-MOFs agreed with those of MIL-88A [42], MIL-101(Fe) [56], Fe-MOF-74 [43], and MIL-100(Fe) [57], which suggests successful synthesis of Fe-MOFs. Conversely, the reduced diffraction peak intensities of used Fe-MOFs indicated that the crystalline structures of MOFs were partially decomposed by the ROS attacks, which is matched with the weight loss and decreased textural properties. However, it is noted that the degree of structural deterioration varied depending on the type of Fe-MOF. Although the weight loss was relatively small, the peak intensity of MIL-88A decreased after the reaction. Despite the tightly packed linkers within its narrow pores [55], it seems that the structure of aliphatic carboxylate ligand-coordinated MIL-88A was relatively unstable compared to other MOFs with aromatic linkers under oxidative reaction conditions. On the contrary, the used Fe-MOF-74 and MIL-100(Fe) exhibited similar diffraction patterns to the fresh ones, suggesting that their structures were retained despite the weight loss due to metal leaching during the CWPO-I reaction. Particularly, there were little changes in the diffraction peaks of MIL-100(Fe) after the reaction, implying its excellent stability under highly oxidative reaction conditions. It was reported that organic linkers containing phenyl carboxylate groups may tend to show greater structural stability when exposed to water and/or oxidizing substances compared to their linear counterparts. This can be attributed to either the π-π stacking interactions between the aromatic groups or the hydrophobicity of these groups, thereby providing additional stabilization energy to the MOFs [53,58]. However, the significantly diminished diffraction peak intensities of used MIL-101(Fe) indicated that the MIL-101(Fe) structure connected with aromatic dicarboxylate ligands was subject to collapse due to fast iron leaching caused by ROS attack. The catalyst recycling test revealed that the structural deformation of the catalyst had a crucial impact on its reaction performance for the CWPO-I of MO (Fig. 2). In the cases of recycled MIL-88A and MIL-101(Fe), there were 42 % and 53 % reductions in the MO degradation rates compared to those of the fresh catalysts. However, the reaction performances of used Fe-MOF-74 and MIL-100(Fe) were slightly decreased, attributed to the relatively smaller decrease in crystallinity and textural properties during the CWPO-I reaction. These results suggest that the Fe metal nodes within the MOF structure are responsible for promoting the CWPO-I reaction, and that the Fe aggregates formed after the structural collapse have little catalytic activity. 3.3 CWPO-II over Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts To implement the CWPO-II scheme without adding ready-made H2O2, an efficient bifunctional catalyst with two distinct active sites is necessary. The first active site should render the preferential dissociation of H2 over O2, thereby facilitating the in-situ generation of H2O2 (DSHP). The second active site should enable the efficient conversion of the resulting H2O2 to ROS, thus promoting MO decomposition. In this context, Pd was newly introduced on Fe-MOFs to enable the in-situ generation of H2O2 from air (O2) and hydrogen. Due to the thermal instability of Fe-MOFs at conventional calcination temperatures above 673 K, the alcohol-reduction method was adopted for Pd impregnation at ambient temperature, despite the challenge in controlling the amount of metal loading and the NP size. The PXRD patterns of Pd/Fe-MOFs were compared with those of Fe-MOFs. As presented in Fig. S3, there were minimal changes in the PXRD patterns of Fe-MOFs, indicating that additional Pd impregnation has little impact on the Fe-MOF structures. Furthermore, the absence of distinct diffraction peaks for metallic Pd might be attributed to low Pd loading (2 wt %), small NP size, and/or the formation of low-crystalline NPs. Similar trends in Pd NP formation by the alcohol-reduction method were reported elsewhere [59,60]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Pd/Fe-MOFs shown in Fig. S4 and Table S2 indicate that both surface area and pore volume of Fe-MOFs decreased after Pd impregnation. This result suggests that the cavities of Fe-MOFs were partially occupied or blocked by Pd NPs, while the Fe-MOF structures were preserved. To examine the dispersion of Pd NPs on Fe-MOFs, TEM analysis was conducted, and the results are presented in Fig. 5 . It was found that the Pd NP size decreased in the order of Pd/MIL-88A (14.94 ± 2.61 nm) > Pd/Fe-MOF-74 (6.58 ± 1.48 nm) > Pd/MIL-100(Fe) (4.89 ± 1.80 nm) > Pd/MIL-101(Fe) (2.69 ± 0.60 nm). The smaller Pd NP formation on MIL-101(Fe) and MIL-100(Fe) suggests that their large surface areas are beneficial in providing sufficient sites for the adsorption of Pd ions. However, the dispersion of Pd NPs on MIL-101(Fe) was higher compared to that on MIL-100(Fe) despite its smaller surface area, implying that other parameters, such as the adsorption strength of Pd ions on supporting materials, might be involved in determining the size of Pd NPs. In the case of Pd/MIL-88A, the observed large Pd NPs on MIL-88A might result from unfavorable aggregation, indicating weak interaction of Pd NPs with the MIL-88A surface. It seems that the surface of MIL-88A, consisting of Fe clusters and aliphatic carboxylate ligands, is undesirable for the strong adsorption of Pd ions, which can be supported by the formation of small Pd NPs on Fe-MOF-74 with aromatic linkers despite its smaller surface area compared to those of MIL-101(Fe) and MIL-100(Fe). Electronic properties of Pd on various Fe-MOFs were investigated by XPS analyses, and the Pd 3d XPS spectra and their deconvoluted chemical states are presented in Fig. 6 . The deconvoluted spectra exhibited a consistent pattern; four deconvoluted peaks were observed in the Pd 3d XPS spectra of each catalyst. Two strong peaks were observed at binding energies (BE) of approximately 336.5 and 341.8 eV, attributed to metallic Pd (Pd0) 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively. On the other hand, two weaker shoulder peaks at BEs of 337.8 and 343.4 eV were assigned to ionic Pd (Pd2+) in the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively [61,62]. Although the population of metallic Pd was higher than its ionic counterpart regardless of the Pd/Fe-MOF types as a result of alcohol reduction, the actual supported Pd content and its Pd2+/Pd0 ratio were highly dependent on the surface nature of a Fe-MOF as summarized in Fig. 7 . There was no apparent relationship between surface area and actual Pd loading amount. For example, while the highest amount of Pd was supported on the MIL-100(Fe) bearing the highest surface area, the lowest amount of Pd was loaded on MIL-101(Fe) among the Pd/Fe-MOFs, despite the surface area of MIL-101(Fe) being approximately 55 and 7 times higher than those of MIL-88A and Fe-MOF-74, respectively. The result indicates that while highly porous Fe-MOFs would be beneficial in offering sufficient adsorption sites, the compatibility of their surfaces for adsorbing metal ions, such as electronic properties and/or hydrophilicity, is also an important factor in determining the efficiency of metal loading. The surface nature of each Fe-MOF also exerted large influence on the electronic properties of Pd and therefore on the interaction between Pd and Fe. The Pd2+/Pd0 ratio, one of the important factors affecting the activity of a Pd catalyst for DSHP, increased in the order of Pd/Fe-MOF-74 < MIL-88A < Pd/MIL-101(Fe) < Pd/MIL-100(Fe) (Fig. 7). Moreover, the 3d5/2 peak shift observed in the 3d XPS spectrum of Pd/Fe-MOF-74 suggests a strong interaction between the Pd NPs and Fe metal nodes (Fig. 6). The efficiencies of different Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts for MO degradation via the CWPO-II reaction were evaluated, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 and Fig. S5. It was found that the MO decomposition rate in the CWPO-II reaction strongly depended on the characteristics of each Pd/Fe-MOF catalyst, following the order: Pd/MIL-88A < MIL-101(Fe) < Fe-MOF-74 < MIL-100(Fe). While Fe-MOF-74 exhibited the best performance in the CWPO-I of MO, the MO degradation efficiency of the Pd/Fe-MOF-74 catalyst via the CWPO-II pathway was second only to that of Pd/MIL-100(Fe). In the case of CWPO-II with Pd/Fe-MOF-74 catalyst, the MO degradation rate was slower than that observed in CWPO-I using Fe-MOF-74 catalyst. This difference could be attributed to the relatively low H2O2 concentration in the CWPO-II reaction, resulting from the in-situ generation of H2O2. There was little difference in the MO degradation rate between CWPO-I with MIL-88A and CWPO-II with Pd/MIL-88A. Conversely, it was surprising to observe that the MO degradation rates of CWPO-II increased by 24.1 % and 20.2 % in the presence of Pd/MIL-101(Fe) and Pd/MIL-100(Fe), respectively, compared to those of CWPO-I with Fe-MOF analogues. It is noteworthy that the MO degradation rate of Pd/SiO2 was only slightly higher than its adsorption rate, indicating that Pd alone scarcely promoted MO degradation. This suggests that only a small amount of MO was decomposed by the in-situ generated H2O2 catalyzed by Pd. In contrast, the MO degradation rate of MIL-100(Fe) was lower than its adsorption rate, implying that H2O2 was not generated in the presence of MIL-100(Fe), and thus the CWPO-II reaction did not proceed (Table S3). The superior CWPO-II performance of these catalysts in MO degradation strongly suggests that H2O2 was generated in sufficient amount such that it no longer limited the MO decomposition rate. Moreover, from a mechanistic perspective, the use of hydrogen in a CWPO-II reaction could facilitate the rate-determining step of the Fenton cycle. As shown in Fig. 9 , the chemisorbed and dissociated hydrogen on Pd NPs may accelerate the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+, thereby enhancing the regeneration of the iron active site [24,63–65]. In addition, although the MO degradation rates of recycled catalysts were lower than those of fresh ones, it is noteworthy that the differences were smaller than those observed in CWPO-I, regardless of the Fe-MOF type. This result suggests that the CWPO-II reaction scheme also offers an advantage in terms of catalyst longevity. 3.4 Direct synthesis, decomposition, and hydrogenation of H2O2 The DSHP reaction was conducted to evaluate the efficiency of each Pd/Fe-MOF catalyst for H2O2 generation and, thereby, to rationalize the differences in CWPO-II reaction performance among Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts. Since all reaction pathways involved in the DSHP are thermodynamically favorable, and the active metal Pd may facilitate both H2O2 formation and its subsequent decomposition and hydrogenation, the H2O2 productivity of each catalyst may be determined by the combined effects of its activity in these reaction pathways [49,66]. Therefore, the trends in H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation over different Pd/Fe-MOF catalysts were also examined. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), The order of H2O2 productivity for each Pd/Fe-MOF catalyst precisely matched that of its CWPO-II reaction rate, clearly demonstrating that the H2O2 productivity of a catalyst significantly influenced its MO degradation rate. It is noted that no H2O2 could not be generated in the presence of the MIL-100(Fe) catalyst alone (Table S4), which clearly suggested that Pd is responsible for H2O2 generation. The variation in H2O2 productivity can be explained by differences in NP size and/or the electronic properties of Pd impregnated on different Fe-MOFs. The largest Pd NP size and a low Pd²⁺/Pd⁰ ratio may be responsible for the lowest H2O2 productivity observed in Pd/MIL-88A. In the case of Pd/MIL-101(Fe), significant H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation may lead to lower H2O2 productivity, despite its smallest Pd NP size and relatively higher Pd²⁺/Pd⁰ ratio as shown in Fig. 10(b) and (c). Interestingly, the H2O2 productivity of Pd/Fe-MOF-74 is higher than that of Pd/MIL-101(Fe), despite Pd/Fe-MOF-74 appearing less favorable in terms of Pd NP size and electronic properties compared to Pd/MIL-101(Fe). The reduced H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation over Fe-MOF-74 suggest that its surface properties are more favorable for suppressing these side reactions. The smaller Pd NP size and the highest Pd²⁺/Pd⁰ ratio in Pd/MIL-100(Fe) were beneficial for suppressing undesirable H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation, and thus, might enhance H2O2 productivity. These results suggest that, in addition to Pd characteristics such as NP size and electronic properties, the surface property of Fe-MOF also play a crucial role in achieving high H2O2 productivity. 3.5 Catalyst recycling test To further assess the reusability of the Pd/MIL-100(Fe) catalyst in the CWPO-II reaction, recycling experiments were extended to the third cycle. The catalytic performance of Pd/MIL-100(Fe) slightly decreased over successive recycling cycles, retaining approximately 92.5 % of the MO degradation rate and 93.9 % of MO conversion after three reuses, respectively, as presented in Fig. 11 (a). As summarized in Table S5, although the extent of Fe leaching from Pd/MIL-100(Fe) during the CWPO-II reaction was significantly lower than that from MIL-100(Fe) during CWPO-I, both Fe and Pd leaching were still observed. Therefore, the decreased catalytic activity may be attributed to the undesirable metal leaching during CWPO-II reaction and the unavoidable partial loss of the catalyst during recovery after the reaction. However, it is noteworthy that, unlike the CWPO-I reaction using pre-added H2O2, the crystalline structure of MIL-100(Fe) remained intact even after four cycles under CWPO-II reaction conditions (Fig. 11(b)). These results clearly demonstrate the excellent recyclability of Pd/MIL-100(Fe) in the CWPO-II reaction. As shown in Fig. 12 (a), DRIFTS analysis was performed to gain deeper insight into the structural stability of MIL-100(Fe) in CWPO-I and Pd/MIL-100(Fe) in CWPO-II, respectively. The characteristic peaks in the MIL-100(Fe) spectrum appeared at 634, 725, 769, 1409, 1469, and 1658 cm⁻¹, corresponding to the vibrations of Fe–O, C–H, and C = O bonds. This confirms the presence of dicarboxylate linkers and iron-oxo clusters, consistent with previous reports [67,68]. Importantly, the spectra of the recovered MIL-100(Fe) and Pd/MIL-100(Fe) were almost identical to those of their fresh counterparts, suggesting their remarkable stability under CWPO-I and CWPO-II reaction conditions. Moreover, as confirmed by the XPS analysis shown in Fig. 12(b), there were negligible changes in the electronic properties of the Pd species on MIL-100(Fe), which may further contribute to the exceptional recyclability of the Pd/MIL-100(Fe) catalyst in the CWPO-II reaction. TEM-EDX mapping analyses in Fig. 13 showed that there was little aggregation between Pd NPs despite slight increase in the Pd NP size, indicating that the distribution of Pd NPs on MIL-100(Fe) could be retained under the CWPO-II reaction condition. Based on the above results, the CWPO-II reaction using the Pd/MIL-100(Fe) catalyst demonstrates excellent MO degradation efficiency and recyclability. These findings suggest that continuous purification of real wastewater is feasible in a CSTR reactor system, wherein organic dyes can be effectively decomposed by the Pd/MIL-100(Fe) catalyst with in-situ H2O2 generation via the simultaneous supply of H2 and air. 4 Conclusion Although Fenton-like reactions are considered environmentally benign and efficient for wastewater treatment, their inherent dosage-dependent nature requires substantial amounts of metal salts and oxidants to generate sufficient reactive oxygen species (ROS). This, in turn, leads to undesirable sludge formation, posing an additional burden on ecosystems and necessitating complex, energy-intensive post-treatment processes. To address these challenges, we propose a highly efficient catalytic wet peroxide oxidation (CWPO) approach that overcomes the limitations of conventional Fenton-like reactions. In this study, a series of Fe-based metal-organic frameworks (Fe-MOFs), including MIL-88A, MIL-101(Fe), Fe-MOF-74, and MIL-100(Fe), along with their Pd-supported counterparts (Pd/Fe-MOFs), were synthesized and evaluated for their catalytic activity in the CWPO of methyl orange (MO). Two reaction pathways were investigated: CWPO-I, which utilizes pre-added H2O2, and CWPO-II, where H2O2 is generated in situ. In CWPO-I, the nature of the organic linkers played a crucial role in determining the MO degradation rate, with Fe-MOF-74 exhibiting the highest efficiency and stability among the Fe-MOF catalysts. However, significant weight loss observed in all Fe-MOFs after the reaction suggests that the coordinated MOF structures were vulnerable to ROS attacks, leading to metal leaching regardless of the ligand type. Conversely, Pd/MIL-101(Fe) and Pd/MIL-100(Fe) in CWPO-II outperformed their Fe-MOF analogues in CWPO-I, achieving higher MO degradation rates. This superior performance strongly suggests that H2O2 was generated in sufficient amounts, preventing any retardation of the MO decomposition rate. Moreover, Pd/MIL-100(Fe) was successfully recycled three times without apparent loss of catalytic activity, demonstrating exceptional stability under CWPO-II reaction conditions. It is noteworthy that the CWPO-II approach utilizing in-situ generated H2O2 offers both economic and environmental advantages over conventional dosage-dependent Fenton-like reactions that rely on excessive amount of commercially available H2O2. These advantages can be summarized as follows: First, the direct synthesis of H2O2 reduces the cost associated with external H2O2 supply. Second, minimizing the use of H2O2 provides a more sustainable water treatment strategy by reducing the addition and formation of undesirable chemical by-products that may negatively impact the environment. coredata.dc:description: This study aimed to develop an elegant strategy to overcome the limitations of conventional dosage-dependent Fenton-like reactions, which require excessive use of metal salts and oxidants, inevitably leading to sludge formation and necessitating complex, energy-intensive post-treatment before disposal into the environment. To achieve this goal, catalytic wet peroxide oxidation (CWPO) was explored using both pre-added H2O2 (CWPO-I) and in-situ generated H2O2 (CWPO-II). For this purpose, four different Fe-based metal-organic frameworks (Fe-MOFs), e.g., MIL-88A, MIL-101(Fe), Fe-MOF-74, and MIL-100(Fe), along with their Pd-supported counterparts (Pd/Fe-MOFs) were prepared and evaluated for their catalytic activity in the CWPO of methyl orange (MO). Although Fe-MOFs effectively promoted the CWPO-I of MO, their coordinated structures were highly susceptible to reactive oxygen species (ROS) attacks, resulting in significant mass loss and decreased catalytic activity after the reaction. In contrast, Pd/Fe-MOFs demonstrated excellent stability in CWPO-II, suggesting that the relatively low H2O2 concentration generated in-situ helped preserve the Fe-MOF structures and maintain their catalytic activity. Furthermore, the MO degradation rates of Pd/MIL-101(Fe) and Pd/MIL-100(Fe) in CWPO-II (1361 and 1992 × 10–5 mmol/h, respectively) exceeded those of their counterparts in CWPO-I (1097 and 1657 × 10–5 mmol/h, respectively). This superior efficiency can be attributed to the sufficient in-situ generation of H2O2 on Pd sites and the subsequent efficient ROS generation on Fe nodes. Pd/MIL-100(Fe) exhibited the highest MO degradation rate and excellent recyclability, maintaining its catalytic activity over four cycles. These findings clearly demonstrate that the CWPO-II approach, leveraging in-situ generated H2O2, offers an efficient wastewater treatment strategy without the need for additional chemicals that could negatively impact the ecosystem.
